home.title: The free alternative to photo-mapping territories
home.description: Panoramax is a digital resource for sharing and exploiting field photos. Anyone can take photographs of places visible from the public highway and contribute them to the Panoramax database. This data is then freely accessible and reusable by all.
home.howItWorks_description: Panoramax federates initiatives (by local authorities, OSM contributors, IGN, etc.) to promote the emergence of a geo-common of immersive view databases.

about.title: About Panoramax
about.introduction: Check road conditions, inventory street furniture or prepare for work on a distribution network... Every year, hundreds of thousands of kilometers are covered by local and regional agents and distribution networks..
about.subtitle_1: 💡 The solution to reduce and facilitate these journeys ?
about.text_1: The use of immersive photo databases. But existing proposals are insufficient : rural areas not covered, old and obsolete data, not free of rights, potentially paying, in the hands of private players capable of changing the rules at any time... Panoramax is the free, independent and open alternative for photo-mapping our territories.
about.text_2: The various communities (AITF, OSM, network operators, IGN, etc.) are bustling with activity, but no real alternative to proprietary "streetview" models is emerging. Panoramax federates these initiatives within the geocommon. 👉 A database of street photos, 360° or not, open and independent : ✔ Contributors upload, manage and share photos ✔ Data hosting is flexible: community members can choose to store their data on their own instance or on the shared instance.. 👉 Community-defined standards and rules of use : ✔ Community-defined technical standards for photo storage and publication ✔ Licences - always free - by instance 👉 Tools and best practices to encourage use : ✔ Automated blurring to anonymize vehicles and people. ✔ Deleting duplicates ✔ Sorting and filtering for easy retrieval of relevant data
about.text_3: Panoramax is not 1, 2 or 3 majority members, but a multiplicity of players who all participate in the community's decisions.. Who makes the decisions? The community is open to any individual or organization wishing to contribute. Members include: ✔ Local authorities, agglomerations, departments, regions, and members of AITF (Association des Ingénieurs territoriaux de France) ✔ Distribution networks (electricity, water, waste management distributors) ✔ OpenStreetMap, the world's open and collaborative map ecosystem ✔ IGN (Institut national de l'information géographique et forestière) ✔ Private players, software or data solutions publishers. You would like to take part in our discussions? join us on the geocommon forum,
about.subtitle_4: 4 phases to design a useful digital service
about.text_4: DINUM (Interministerial digital department) state startup method / Beta.gouv Where do we stand? Following the investigation phase led by IGN intrapreneur Camille Salou, the first investment committee validated the project, which is currently pursuing its construction phase within la Fabrique des Géocommuns, with the help of a small team in charge of its development. The next step? A prototype to be designed and tested by the community by the end of April 2023. At the end of 12 months of development, sharing and pooling, it will be decided whether to enter the acceleration phase, and then to consolidate it to ensure the program's exit.

faq.title: Frequently asked questions : Panoramax and anonymization
faq.introduction_text:
Panoramax is a platform that provides an inventory of photography and online visualization of places visible from the public highway. Supported by IGN's Fabrique des géocommuns, the platform aims to offer an alternative to private « street view » type offerings, by turning this tool into a digital commons.Anyone can take photographs of places to feed the Panoramax database. This data is then distributed online via a platform. They are freely accessible and reusable.
There are legal issues surrounding this data, and it's in this FAQ that we answer some of your questions on this subject..

blocks.title: Am I allowed to upload photographs with people in them to a Panoramax instance?
blocks.text:
1) What French law says : Everyone has the right to an image. This right is based on both the right to privacy and the right to protection of personal data. If you take a photograph of a place and one or more people are there, there are two possible solutions :
  • If the person or persons are identifiable, i.e. it is possible to recognize who they are, then it is necessary to obtain their consent or, failing that, to anonymize the data (e.g. by blurring the person's face).;
  • If the person or persons are not identifiable (e.g. it is not possible to recognize them) then it is not necessary to obtain their consent, nor to anonymize the data.
2) What Panoramax does : People's faces are automatically blurred on the Panoramax instance. So you don't need to do anything when you upload your photos to Panoramax..

blocks.title: What should I do if there are no people in the photograph, but other elements can identify them?
blocks.text:
1) What does French law say :
  • The image of a house visible from the street or a car parked in a public parking lot is not, on its own, personal data within the meaning of Article 4 of the GDPR. Indeed, even if these assets surely have an owner or users, they alone do not allow a person to be re-identified.
  • Attention : The presence of additional elements can nevertheless provide clues to a person's identity. For example, if a license plate is visible on a car, or if a person's first and last name are visible on the mailbox of a house. These are personal data, since they enable one or more people to be identified directly or indirectly.
2) What Panoramax does : Like people, license plates are automatically blurred on Panoramax. Any additional elements to be blurred can be reported on the platform.

blocks.title: Can a private individual prevent me from distributing a photograph of his property on Panoramax?
blocks.text:
1) What does French law say :
  • The owner of a property can only object to the publication of a photograph if it causes him or her an abnormal disturbance of enjoyment. This is the case, for example, if the diffusion of an image causes a tourist influx on a particular site.
  • In the case of dissemination of a photograph on a public viewing tool, the risk of disturbance to the owner of the property is considered to be low..
  • It is therefore not compulsory to systematically blur private property, unless an owner expressly requests it.
2) What Panoramax does : Individuals can report directly to the platform to request additional blurring, if justified.

blocks.title: Are there any buildings whose photographs cannot be distributed for reasons of public safety?
blocks.text:
1) What does French law say :
  • A legal text (the decree of August 28, 1991) prohibits, as a matter of principle, photography in or around military and maritime places, works, stations or establishments or those of national defense interest, unless authorized by the military authority.
  • These buildings can be identified by external signs such as: warning signs (e.g.: "Military land, no trespassing"), the demarcation of a specific area (walls, fences, barbed wire), the presence of military personnel, etc.
2) What Panoramax does : These buildings are a priori blurred on Panoramax. Any missing information can be reported on the service.

blocks.title: What to do if copyrighted works are present in photographs ?
blocks.text:
Step 1 : Check whether the photograph contains original artwork
  • on the public highway, there may be elements that are protected by copyright if their originality can be demonstrated. These include, for example, works of the mind such as architecture, street furniture, sculptures, posters and so on.
Step 2 : If this is the case, the author of an original work must give his or her consent for it to be photographed and distributed online. Caution: There is an exception, if the photograph falls within the panorama exception, which is the case when :
  • the photographer is an individual acting in his or her own name - not on behalf of a public or private organization ;
  • the works depicted in the photograph are architectures and sculptures that are permanently present on the public highway ;
  • the photographs are not intended for commercial use;
  • If you comply with these three conditions, you can distribute the photo on Panoramax without the author's consent.

blocks.title: Do photographers need their consent to distribute their images on the platform?
blocks.text:
1) What French law says :
  • contributors who take photographs for the Panoramax database may hold intellectual property rights on the photographs. In fact, a photograph may be protected by copyright if it is original.
  • However, it should be stressed that the originality of photographs is difficult to demonstrate. Originality can be characterized according to the photographer's choices in terms of composition, framing, angle, light, contrast and color.
2) What Panoramax does :
  • In view of these criteria and the tool itself, the originality of photographs made available on Panoramax seems difficult to demonstrate. There are therefore two possible scenarios :
    • If originality cannot be demonstrated, the photographs will not be covered by copyright.
    • On the other hand, if originality is demonstrated, Panoramax must have the rights to the photographs in order to distribute them within the framework of the platform made available.
  • On the Panoramax / IGN instance, the license used is the Open License, which includes a concession of rights to the reuser..
  • NB : a document of recommendations on how to take photographs in order to standardize shots as much as possible is currently being studied.

faq.summary_title: In short, Panoramax provides solutions for the above-mentioned cases through :
faq.summary_text:
• Automatic anonymization through blurring of faces, license plates and any other element that could - even indirectly - identify a person.
  • The ability to report content that may infringe on people's privacy, property or intellectual property rights.
This FAQ is available to all Panoramax stakeholders, and is updated regularly.

contribute.main_description: Panoramax is a platform that lists photos taken and allows you to view places visible from public roads online. Supported by the IGN Geocommuns Factory, the platform aims to offer an alternative to private “street view” type offers, by making this tool a digital commons. Anyone can take photographs of the places in order to populate the Panoramax database. This data is then distributed online via a platform. They are freely accessible and reusable.
contribute.contribute_desc_photos: Take pictures - 360° or not - with a simple smartphone or any other more sophisticated device.
contribute.contribute_desc_upload: Upload, store and share your photos on the instance of your choice, such as panoramax.ign.fr or panoramax.openstreetmap.fr.
contribute.contribute_desc_map: Discover and use photos shared by the community in the federated catalog, and exploit them for your business needs.

contribute.guide_desc: To make the photos as easily usable as possible, remember to ensure their level of quality. Here is an illustrated example of a beautiful image (left) versus a degraded image (right). For more details, see our best practices guide.
contribute.use_desc_viewer: Browse photos through our interactive web viewer and explore our entire photo catalog.
contribute.use_desc_api: Access photo data and metadata using our web API, compliant with "OGC Feature" and "STAC" standards.
contribute.use_desc_detect: Using artificial intelligence, we find and classify objects visible in images, such as road signs or street furniture. This data will soon be available to everyone, free of charge and under an open license.
